system 1 thinking is your brain working unconsciously and thank goodness it does
because that regulates heartbeat and breathing and all the biological functions that go on your body that
happened largely and almost exclusively unconsciously system 2 is what
neuroscientists call conscious thought that's what we may be aware of and both of those types of thinking generate
responses now a neuroscientist friend David Eagleman characterizes what goes

endpoint and that's really what goes on in our brain between our unconscious thoughts and our conscious thought today
we're going to focus on what happens in the conscious side of your thinking and
a research scientist by the name of Keith Stanovich at the University of
Toronto has has defined system to thinking as type 1 and type 2 because
type 1 thinking algorithmic thinking and algorithmic thinking is a process of
thinking where we apply what we already know in a systematic and regular basis
it's very important to cognitive processing because if we had two reconsent relies every move of every day
our lives would be torturous so our brain take shortcuts it creates frames
and it creates algorithms and it reapplies them and from that comes a response however every so often we
encounter something that doesn't match one of our pre-existing frames and it kicks us out of algorithmic thinking
into what he calls type 2 or reflective thinking this is a process where we uptake information into our working
memory hippocampus amygdala DES we use lots of different systems in our brain and we simulate potential responses and
then ultimately we choose a response and it's this articulation between type 1 algorithmic
and type 2 reflective thinking that really begins to define what we do with design thinking the first perspective
would like to talk about deals with work and empathy and defining what the design
problem is and it has to do with framing Erving Goffman in the early 70s
identified this as a concept and what it is is it's a schema of interpretation a

this picture was actually drawn in the late 1800s and it's been studied quite extensively and your brain will frame
that in one of two ways largely dependent on who you are not surprisingly men tend to frame it as a
young woman women tend to frame it as an older woman in that context but it's your brain creating a frame around that
picture that is algorithmic thinking that system one thinking and what we
need to do as designers is to learn first of all that that frame exists then
find a way to break that frame apart and then reassemble that frame in a different sort of way and that's the

cognitive neuroscience spent a lot of time thinking about particularly in the context of economics as people make
risky or less risky choices as they relate to to economics it's important
for us to distinguish first of all that there are different kinds of risks and in this case particularly risk in the
context of ambiguity we know as human beings that the choices we make lead to
specific outcomes and sometimes those outcomes are good and some kind of sometimes they're bad and as our brain
processes it really processes two kinds of risk the first is what we will call just risk
and that's where the rules and the probability of an outcome are well known well sensed or well understood and games
of chance gambling games are an example of that our brain processes that in one sort of way there are other kinds of
risky problems we come up against which are called ambiguous problems that's where the rules and the probabilities of
the outcome are unknown the picture on the lower right hand side is a picture of the Spanish influenza virus and what
what that's indicative of is when situations like a pandemic occur don't
really know how how they spread where they'll spread and what the implications
of them of a virus like that might be and that's really an ambiguous problem
in the design world that's been defined as something called a wicked problem where essentially the parameters of the
problem are not understood well enough to where you can develop any kind of solution with predictability as it turns
out the brain processes this in very different sorts of ways a risk which
we'll say we'll call deductive reasoning where a equals B B equals C and therefore a equals C risk is often
calculated in the cortex the prefrontal cortex specifically and depending on the
type of problem you're solving it will be done asymmetrically the right side or left side in that kind of context
ambiguity on the other hand is often processed in a very different kind of place it's processed in the--in the
inner brain the limbic system and brain systems like the amygdala the orbital
frontal cortex and the striatal system which is a reward based system will often be recruited as you sort through
ambiguous problems said another way a simpler way is that with ambiguity emotions play a much more significant
role in the process than they do with let's say risky decisions or deductive
decisions so in the world of design fine what we find is that most of the
problems are ambiguous problems you don't have an obvious or logical solution to them so emotions and
understanding emotions becomes an important part of regulating the risk and the definition of ambiguity in that
process so how do we deal with that and let's say the ideation stage again
there's lots of speed bumps given the fact that emotions are involved habit and fear are important contributors as
well as the environment and group dynamics and some of the techniques that we practice our things like stoking
which is a way of connecting your mind and body together in in terms of coming
in contact with your emotions and the way in which you you choose and think we
have techniques where we can impose a constraint so you can only use for example your right hand or you can only
use your hearing to solve a particular problem as a way to understand how you
might get in touch with difficult to define and ambiguous problems we also use an interesting feedback technique
called I like I wish and what if this is important because as feedback is
provided it takes the negative aspects out of it so rather than criticizing someone's idea for what it lacks you
criticize someone's idea for what you like in it you frame how it might be made better as something you wish for
and then you offer suggestions in the context of what if that simple little tool changes the dynamics of
conversations around ideas in a way that takes things from being scary and
ambiguous to more easily understood and risky so let's ask a question now what

well most people are moving towards a risk accepting world and what I would say is that this is a bit of a trick

an animal however that is encoded in our
DNA it's encoded in our thought processes because it was the way in which we survived for hundreds of

expressed as Tim in golden in his book called lines the way we think about this
is perhaps through lines and if you think about a hunter they start in a village and somewhere out there is the

the general area and the hunt ends up looking like a line like this and in
this context you can tell because I told you it's hunting is that it's not wandering because at every step along
the way the hunter is sensing and they're looking that they're in a sense
making choices and decisions about where the actual goal might be and then of
course once the once the hunt is concluded the objective is to bring the the
reindeer back to the village as soon as possible and so these are two very distinctive activities that we as human beings are
comfortable with and in gold calls one of them wayfinding and it calls the
other one transport the issue in today's world particularly in innovation world
is that we're much better at transporting than we are wayfinding our brain and in fact our reward structures
are all about transporting because this isn't until you get the reindeer back to the village that you actually achieve
the benefit of the hunt so the benefit comes at the end of the transporting phase and we are very good at
prosecuting that and understanding that we're not so good at way finding because wayfinding is full of lots of
uncertainty risk and ambiguity and particularly in companies if you were to
take the take the position of I want to spend some time just wandering
oftentimes people might consider that wasteful not a good use of talent
another way of thinking about choices in the context of wayfinding and transporting is in terms of mindset a
convergent mindset and a divergent mindset a GP guildford an American psychologist coined this term in the
1950s as two ways in which you think two ways in which you provide what he calls
mental production in a convergent mode you're looking for a single best
solution to a problem and in a divergent mode you're looking for a variety of
solutions to a problem and what we we've actually done work with this in our lab and what we find is that people
who have a preference for convergent mindsets are interested in facts in fact
in a conversation with people about new product development they will trade
facts over questions meaning they will talk more about the facts and after the conversation will rate the facts more
highly then people of a divergent mindset and people in a divergent mindset have a similar predisposition
towards questions they like questions they introduce questions and after the conversation they rate the questions
that were asked as being more important to the solution than the facts and if you think about it facts tend to close
down options because of factors of fact and questions tend to open up problem spaces or even shift problem spaces and
what we're finding is that people have preferences for each of these kinds of
thinking the challenge we all face and is that we must do both and we do do
both as as human beings but in a design context when you start with a problem
you go through a period of diversion and then ultimately have to converge because you need to get something done so in all
of us is the ability to diverge and converge the trick and the challenge of course is to choose when to switch when
to go from a divergent mode to a converging ode and of course as you're going through a project you have many
periods of divergence and convergence as you move through each one of those areas so there's a chance for conflict between
divergent thinkers and convergent thinkers in each area and a lot of this has to do with the ability that people
have to shift between convergent and divergent thinking and then of course as I mentioned timing when is the right
time to stop diverging and begin converging or stop converging and begin diverging in the way we work this out in
design thinking is with the concept of prototyping and testing prototyping and
building a prototype is a way to simultaneously diverge and ultimately converge on one design and it testing is
a way to verify it and essentially kick-start the divergent process again this is an example if you will of one of
our classes emmy 3:10 where students will work on the development of a kershel product and over the course of a
three of the three quarter experience they'll develop nine different prototypes that express this one idea
and it starts from an experienced prototype that can be as open and flexible as you might imagine all the
way up to the last prototype they build in May is a reference prototype something that can actually be produced
or scaled the challenge with prototyping if you will in companies is that it
faces several speed bumps first of all is habit we don't build prototypes we build final solutions a big one is fear
failure prototypes by their very nature or design to fail and because they do in
an environment that doesn't value failure they can be fear inducing and so people don't build prototypes there's
also a skill to building prototypes you have to be comfortable doing things that are less than perfect and some people
don't feel comfortable doing that and then finally in a group dynamic context prototypes can be difficult because
everyone might have a different idea and it puts extra emphasis on how you
resolve conflicts over over where you go in the d.school

within a company bring what we call typical skillsets to bear so for example
we find that engineers are mostly convergent thinkers although not not

other people on your team and at the same time internalize those differences
